awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mitochondrial DNA lineages and host-pathogen dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Mitochondria are the parts of cells that help the body produce energy. They have their own genetic information, which varies within and across human populations and has been used to reconstruct human population history. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate fundamental questions about the role of human mitochondrial (mtDNA) variation in human evolution by focusing on mitochondrial metabolism and its association with infection risk. Different mtDNA lineages vary in the extent of their energy production and corresponding amounts of damaging reaction oxygen species (ROS) created by this process. The levels of ROS may create different thresholds for the development of health problems associated with mitochondrial damage. The results of this study will provide insights into the role of adaptation in human energy metabolism and the biological trade-offs involved with human-pathogen evolution. This project will support graduate and undergraduate training in molecular anthropological methods, and the findings of this project may inform public health research focused on disease risk in modern human populations.

The researchers will assess whether mtDNA lineages are associated with increased or decreased cancer risk in women infected with human papilloma virus. Samples for genetic analysis of mtDNA lineage and viral typing will be obtained from women in the Philadelphia area. Demographic and health variables will be incorporated into a logistic regression model to assess the effect of mtDNA lineage. The relationships among geographic variants of the two most common high-risk types of human papilloma virus, cervical cancer precursors, and mtDNA lineage status will be further examined to explore possible host-virus co-evolution.

por.por_cntn:
Research has suggested that differences in metabolic efficiency between different mitochondrial backgrounds affects transformation and proliferation of malignant cells and therefore the risk of developing cancers. Studies have shown that increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, a by-product of OXPHOS, creates mtDNA and membrane damage, driving malignant transformation of cells Among women, human papilloma virus (HPV) proteins interact with the epithelial cells of the cervix, including the cell mitochondria, and can potentially cause cervical cancer.

To further investigate the relationship between mitochondrial background, HPV infection and precancer development, we studied a diverse group of women from the Philadelphia area. We obtained a large number of DNA samples for analysis from cervical swab samples at the Molecular Pathology Laboratory at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania (HUP) that had been tested for HPV using a Roche Cobas system. Although over 2,800+ samples were screened for the presence of mtDNA and HPV DNA, due to poor sample quality, only 122 were successfully Sanger sequenced, with a further 96 sequenced using Next generation sequencing (Illumina NovaSeq 6000).

The sequenced  mtDNA of the samples were classified into known maternal lineages or haplogroups: West Eurasian (H, HV, J, K, N, T, U, W); East Eurasian (B4, C4, D5, F, M, R, Z); African (L0, L1, L2 and L3); Amerindian haplogroups (A2, B2, C1, D1). This effort revealed that 40.1% of their mtDNAs were West Eurasian, 7.4% East Eurasian, 3.4% Amerindian, and 49.0% African mitochondrial IN ancestry. In addition, 26 different HPV types were identified including the high risk types 16, 18, 31, 35, 39, 45, 52, 53, 56, 58, 59, 66, and 68.

Multivariate ordinal logistic regressions were run using data for Pap cytology (NILM, LSIL and HSIL/cancer), mtDNA ancestry, and HPV infection, adjusted by socio-demographic variables collected from the Data Analytics Center (DAC). Statistical analysis showed that there was no association between mtDNA type and precancer status, although women with Amerindian ancestry had a greater risk of developing cervical cancer when positive with high-risk type HPV-16 or HPV-16/-18 (OR of 3.18 and 3.3, respectively) although this finding was not significant (p>0.05). However, being a current smoker was associated with increased risk for developing cervical cancer precursors in the presence of HPV-16 and HPV-16/HPV-18 infection (OR = 4.4 and 4.2, respectively; p < 0.05).

Overall, this study has contributed to our understanding of the genetic and sociocultural risk factors that influence cervical cancer development in the northeastern United States. Larger scale studies are needed to confirm our findings and evaluate the relative risk that different mtDNA haplogroups confer on cervical cancer incidence. The collection of cervical swabs from Pathology Departments that do not conduct prior HPV testing may provide better opportunities to gather large sample sizes provided that the participating laboratory has the biosafety accreditation for analyses and ability to store whole cell samples that may carry infectious diseases.

            To date, this project has produced one published peer-review manuscript and two additional papers in preparation for publication. A graduate and undergraduate student were trained in evolutionary theory, genetic wet lab techniques, project development, and bioinformatics during the undertaking of this project. The results of this research were initially presented at the Human Biology Association (HBA) meetings in 2021, with a full description of the main findings presented at the 2023 HBA meetings.
